thread.title: Florida's first bear hunt in decades underway
thread.title_full: Florida's first bear hunt in decades underway

title: Florida's first bear hunt in decades underway
text:
Florida's first bear hunt in decades underway 207 of 320 allowed killed on first day POSTED: 9 mins Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission SORRENTO, Fla. - 
Hunters killed 207 black bears in Florida Saturday, two-thirds of the total allowed to be taken during the state's first hunting season for the animal in decades years, state Fish and Wildlife officials said. Related Obama administration announces new... 
The FWC said the season is now over in the Central and East Panhandle bear management units because their quotas have been met. Hunting will continue Sunday in the North and South management areas, Bay News 9 in St. Petersburg reported . 
The FWC set the statewide quota for the first black bear hunt since 1994 at 320, the Orlando Sentinel reported . Nearly 3,800 bear-hunting permits had been issued in Florida as of Friday. The FWC's website says the state has an estimated 3,000 bears, up from 300-500 in 1974. 
"The harvest objective was set as the number we want to achieve to stabilize the growing populations," the newspaper quoted FWC spokeswoman Susan Smith as saying. "When we set them, we did so with allowable range, recognizing that the harvest may exceed the objective." 
The bear hunting season has drawn protests. Speak Up Wekiva unsuccessfully sued to try and stop the hunt. It's volunteers monitored the hunt from check-in stations and urged officials to call off the hunt Saturday evening, the Sentinel said.
